to look at the data was we took to
publicly available data sources from the
National Highway Traffic Safety
Administration or Nitsa one that they
have available is their FAR's data it's
a census of all motor vehicle accidents
that involve fatality in the United
States the other one is their general
estimate system or GES that is a sample
of all types of motor vehicle accidents
and it's waited to be nationally
representative so we took these two data
sets and first we just kind of looked at
the change over the last ten years so
from 2004 to 2010 we found that overall
the number of fatalities went down motor
vehicle fatalities went down but if you
looked at pedestrians and cyclists they
actually represented a growing portion
of all those fatalities so pedestrians
for example in 2004 made up just under
11 percent of all motor vehicle
fatalities and in 2013 they were up to
14 and a half or about fifteen percent
of all of those fatalities so we kind of
gave the perspective of what had been
happening over time and then for 2013
which was the most

drug price under Part D for those that
changing basket of generic drugs so
that's the foul line and then the sort

established basket of drugs and so what

which Gao defines as a price increase of
100 or more percent over a given year
that's what we did for this report and
we found that for the basket of drugs
that we were looking at is just the
established basket so those for the
whole time period we found that about
300 of those had an extraordinary price
increase and so what you're kind of
looking at here is over time those are

of one hundred to two hundred percent
all the way up to a thousand or more
